body: Can we make it possible to toggle this behaviour? In some cases, reusing connections between iterations can be good (e.g. when you just want to push out as many TPS as possible and avoid the overhead of having to create new connections all the time)
I kinda question the usefulness of this, but I'd like some other opinions on it… @robingustafsson

@ragnarlonn Could you not create the same behavior by having a while-true loop?

The default should IMO be to reset connections.

ok, I agree that keeping connections alive over iterations is an edge case so doing it in a while-true loop is fine.

  /Ragnar

FYI I have a use case where a load balancer (BigIP F5 as usual...) maintains sessions by SSL connection ID. Not a good choice since you cannot control how connections are reused by the client, especially across proxies but it is what it is. It would be good to be able to control how connections are reused across iterations.
A `while(true)` loop will never report any metrics, because the last iteration of a script is always discarded, but again - what is the use case here?
@liclac What does "shared transport" mean? Does it imply VUs will share tcp connections?

@liclac I still get problems running e.g. 50 VUs and a script that iterates very quickly. I found that it can be fixed by increasing MaxIdleConnsPerHost for the TCP transport, according to the answer to this SO question: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/39813587/go-client-program-generates-a-lot-a-sockets-in-time-wait-state

When I add those params I can use a couple of hundred VUs before I run into another issue: DNS lookups start to fail.

```
ERRO[0003] GoError: Get http://test.loadimpact.com: dial tcp: lookup test.loadimpact.com: no such host
	at native
```

That behaviour is related to a lack of file descriptors (ulimit -n). Increasing the number of allowed open files fixes it and I can use a lot more VUs.

The first problem should be possible to fix by upping MaxIdleConnsPerHost when creating the HTTP transport I assume, but the 2nd problem may not be easily fixable by us while still being something users commonly encounter. Perhaps it would be possible to catch the DNS lookup errors and add some hint to the user like "Perhaps you're running out of file descriptors?  use `ulimit -n` to increase max number of open fds"

I *want* to just cache DNS lookups and exclude that from metrics, because it's not a very useful metric - the results depend entirely on infrastructure wholly unrelated from the system you're actually trying to test. See #41.

What I just did was explicitly disable HTTP keepalives; the shared transport is mostly preparation for some kind of optimization here, but I'm honestly not well enough versed in the semantics of this to tell if there's a real difference between an idle connection and keep-alive…

I'd say: yes, cache DNS lookups and remove the DNS lookup time metric for now. We can reintroduce it later, if people seem to want it. It is better to remove this potential road block for novice users than keep a metric noone is likely to use.

And keeping a socket pool per VU and reusing those sockets between iterations by default sounds like a good idea to me.
VUs now have their own connection pools, needs a commandline switch to disable.

Thanks so much - adding the following in options helped me greatly:
    noConnectionReuse: true
my connections close the socket with a FIN/ACK appropriately after each vu iteration, and new connections are seen with a proper SYN sequence for each subsequent vu iteration.
